{{about|the explorer|the scientist|William Cecil Dampier}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = William Dampier | image = Dampier-portrait.jpg | alt = Oil on canvas portrait of Dampier holding a book | caption = Portrait of Dampier holding his book, a painting by [[Thomas Murray (artist)|Thomas Murray]] (c. 1697–1698) | birth_date = Baptised {{nowrap|5 September 1651}} | birth_place = [[East Coker]], [[Somerset]], England | death_date = March 1715 (aged 64) | death_place = [[London]], England | nationality = British | known_for = Exploring and mapping Australia, [[Circumnavigation]] | occupation = Privateer and explorer | spouse = Judith Dampier }}
'''William Dampier''' (baptised 5 September 1651;<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article58702944 |title=Out of the Library |newspaper=[[The Sunday Times (Western Australia)|The Sunday Times]] |location=Perth, W.A. |date=3 September 1933 |accessdate=7 February 2012 |page=17, Sect. A |publisher=National Library of Australia}} </ref> died March 1715) was an English explorer and navigator who became the first Englishman to explore parts of what is today [[Australia]], and the first person to [[Circumnavigation|circumnavigate]] the world three times. He has also been described as Australia's first natural historian,<ref>{{cite book|last=George |first=Alexander S. |year=1999 |title=William Dampier in New Holland: Australia's First Natural Historian |location=Hawthorn, Vic. |publisher=Bloomings Books |isbn=978-187-64-7312-9}}</ref> as well as one of the most important British explorers of the period between [[Sir Walter Raleigh]] and [[James Cook]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Preston |first1=Diana |last2=Preston |first2=Michael |lastauthoramp = y |year=2005 |title=A Pirate of Exquisite Mind: The Life of William Dampier |location=New York |publisher=Walker & Company |isbn=978-038-56-0705-6 |page=5}}</ref>
After impressing the [[Admiralty]] with his book ''A New Voyage Round the World'', Dampier was given command of a [[Royal Navy]] ship and made important discoveries in western Australia, before being court-martialled for cruelty. On a later voyage he rescued [[Alexander Selkirk]], a former crewmate who may have inspired [[Daniel Defoe]]'s ''[[Robinson Crusoe]]''. Others influenced by Dampier include [[James Cook]], [[Horatio Nelson]], [[Charles Darwin]], and [[Alfred Russel Wallace]].
==Early Life== William Dampier was born at [[Hymerford House]] in [[East Coker]], [[Somerset]], in 1651. He was baptised on 5 September, but his precise date of birth is not recorded. He was educated at [[King's School, Bruton]].<ref>[http://www1.somerset.gov.uk/archives/ Somerset Archives]. Records of King's School, Bruton.</ref> Dampier sailed on two merchant voyages to [[Newfoundland Colony|Newfoundland]] and [[Java]] before joining the [[Royal Navy]] in 1673. He took part in the two [[Battle of Schooneveld|Battles of Schooneveld]] in June of that year.
Dampier's service was cut short by a catastrophic illness, and he returned to England for several months of recuperation. For the next several years he tried his hand at various careers, including plantation management in [[Jamaica]] and logging in Mexico, before he eventually joined another sailing expedition.<ref name=Cordingly>{{cite book |last=Cordingly |first=David |title=Under the Black Flag |year=2006 |publisher=Random House |location=New York |page=83 |isbn=978-081-29-7722-6}}</ref> Returning to England, he married Judith around 1679, only to leave for the sea a few months later.<ref>Preston & Preston, ch. III</ref>
==First circumnavigation== [[File:Dampier Mosquito.gif|thumb|left|alt=Engraved map of Central America|Map from Dampier's ''A New Voyage Round the World'' of 1697, with a star marking the [[Mosquito Coast|"Miskito" coast]]]] In 1679, Dampier joined the crew of the [[buccaneer]] Captain [[Bartholomew Sharp]] on the [[Spanish Main]] of Central America, twice visiting the [[Bay of Campeche]], or "Campeachy" as it was then known, on the north coast of Mexico.<ref name="nndb">{{cite web |url=http://www.nndb.com/people/943/000096655/ |title=William Dampier |publisher=NNDB |accessdate=5 September 2009}}</ref> This led to his first circumnavigation, during which he accompanied a raid across the [[Darién Province|Isthmus of Darién]] in Panama and took part in the capture of Spanish ships on the Pacific coast of that isthmus. The pirates then raided Spanish settlements in [[Peru]] before returning to the Caribbean.
Dampier made his way to [[Colony of Virginia|Virginia]], where in 1683 he was engaged by the [[privateer]] John Cooke. Cooke entered the Pacific via [[Cape Horn]] and spent a year raiding Spanish possessions in Peru, the [[Galápagos Islands]], and Mexico.<ref name="nndb"/> This expedition collected buccaneers and ships as it went along, at one time having a fleet of ten vessels. Cooke died in Mexico, and a new leader, [[Edward Davis (buccaneer)|Edward Davis]], was elected [[captain (nautical)|captain]] by the crew, taking the ship ''Batchelor's Delight'', with future Captain [[George Raynor (pirate)|George Raynor]] in the crew.<ref name="Vallar">{{cite web|last1=Vallar|first1=Cindy|title=Pirates & Privateers: the History of Maritime Piracy - A Buccaneer More Interested in Nature than Gold|url=http://www.cindyvallar.com/Dampier.html|website=www.cindyvallar.com|accessdate=30 June 2017}}</ref>
Dampier transferred to the privateer [[Charles Swan (pirate)|Charles Swan]]'s ship, ''Cygnet'', and on 31 March 1686 they set out across the Pacific to raid the [[Dutch East Indies|East Indies]], calling at [[Guam]] and [[Mindanao]]. Spanish witnesses saw the predominantly English crew as not only pirates and heretics but also cannibals. Leaving Swan and 36 others behind on Mindanao, the rest of the privateers sailed on to [[Manila]], [[Côn Sơn Island|Poulo Condor]], China, the [[Maluku Islands|Spice Islands]], and [[New Holland (Australia)|New Holland]]. Contrary to Dampier's later claim that he had not actively participated in actual piratical attacks during this voyage, he was in fact selected in 1687 to command one of the Spanish ships captured by ''Cygnet''{{'}}s crew off Manila.<ref>{{cite book |last=López-Lázaro |first=Fabio |title=The Misfortunes of Alonso Ramírez: The True Adventures of a Spanish American with 17th-Century Pirates |year=2011 |publisher=University of Texas Press |location=Austin, Texas |pages=29–30 |isbn=978-029-27-4389-2}}</ref>
On 5 January 1688, ''Cygnet'' "anchored two miles from shore in 29 fathoms" on the northwest coast of Australia, near [[King Sound]].<ref>Abbott, J. H. M., ''William Dampier'', [[Sydney]], 1911, p.55-6.</ref> Dampier and his ship remained there until March 12, and while the ship was being [[careening|careened]] Dampier made notes on the fauna and flora and the indigenous peoples he found there.<ref>Abbott, 1911, pp. 56-62.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70346899 |title=Ocean Paths |newspaper=The Central Queensland Herald |location=Rockhampton, Qld. |date=20 February 1936 |accessdate=7 February 2012 |page=60 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Among his fellows were a significant number of Spanish sailors, most notably Alonso Ramírez, a native of [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Sigüenza y Góngora |first=Carlos de |title=Infortunios de Alonso Ramírez |year=2011 |publisher=Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas–Polifemo |location=Madrid |page=166, n. 274 |isbn=978-840-00-9365-5}}</ref> Later that year, by agreement, Dampier and two shipmates were marooned on one of the [[Nicobar Islands]]. They obtained a small canoe which they modified after first capsizing and then, after surviving a great storm at sea, called at "Acheen" ([[Aceh]]) in [[Sumatra]].
Dampier returned to England in 1691 via the [[Cape of Good Hope]], penniless but in possession of his journals. He also had as a source of income a slave known as Prince Jeoly (or Giolo), from [[Miangas]] (now Indonesia), who became famous for his tattoos (or "paintings" as they were known at the time). Dampier exhibited Jeoly in [[London]], thereby also generating publicity for a book based on his diaries.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Barnes |first=Geraldine |year=2006 |title=Curiosity, Wonder, and William Dampier's Painted Prince |journal=Journal for Early Modern Cultural Studies |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=31–50 |doi=10.1353/jem.2006.0002}}</ref><ref>Savage, John (c. 1692). [http://acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=153334 "Etching of Prince Giolo"]. State Library of New South Wales.</ref>
==''Roebuck'' expedition== {{See also|HMS Roebuck (1690)}}[[File:Dampier-New Holland plants.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.9|alt=Engraving of plant samples from Australia|Australian plant life from Dampier’s ''A Voyage to New Holland'', published in 1703.]] The publication of the book, ''A New Voyage Round the World'', in 1697 was a popular sensation, creating interest at the [[Admiralty]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=The New World Voyages of William Dampier |journal=Athena Review |volume=1 |issue=2 |url=http://greenfield.fortunecity.com/sunshine/235/dampier-ing.htm |accessdate=8 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000306142148/http://greenfield.fortunecity.com/sunshine/235/dampier-ing.htm |archivedate=6 March 2000 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 1699, Dampier was given command of the 26-gun warship {{HMS|Roebuck|1690|6}}, with a commission from King [[William III of England|William III]] (who had ruled jointly with Queen [[Mary II of England|Mary II]] until her death in 1694).<ref name="adob">{{cite web |url=http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A010265b.htm |title=Dampier, William (1651–1715) |author=Bach, J. |year=1966 |publisher=''Australian Dictionary of Biography'' |accessdate=5 September 2009}}</ref> His mission was to explore the east coast of New Holland, the name given by the Dutch to what is now Australia, and Dampier's intention was to travel there via [[Cape Horn]].
The expedition set out on 14 January 1699, too late in the season to attempt the Horn, so it headed to New Holland via the Cape of Good Hope instead. Following the Dutch route to the Indies, Dampier passed between [[Dirk Hartog Island]] and the Western Australian mainland into what he called [[Shark Bay]] on 6 August 1699. He landed and began producing the first known detailed record of Australian flora and fauna. The botanical drawings that were made are believed to be by his clerk, James Brand. Dampier then followed the coast north-east, reaching the [[Dampier Archipelago]] and [[Lagrange Bay]], just south of what is now called [[Broome, Western Australia|Roebuck Bay]], all the while recording and collecting specimens, including many shells.<ref>{{cite book |last=Marchant |first=Leslie R. |title=An Island Unto Itself: William Dampier and New Holland |year=1988 |publisher=Hesperian Press |location=Victoria Park, W.A. |isbn=978-085-90-5120-0}}</ref> From there he bore northward for [[Timor]]. Then he sailed east and on 3 December 1699 rounded New Guinea, which he passed to the north. He traced the south-eastern coasts of [[New Hanover Island|New Hanover]], [[New Ireland (island)|New Ireland]] and [[New Britain]], [[nautical chart|charting]] the [[Dampier Strait (Papua New Guinea)|Dampier Strait]] between these islands (now the [[Bismarck Archipelago]]) and New Guinea. En route, he paused to collect specimens such as giant clams.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Burney |first1=James |title=A Chronological History of the Discoveries in the South Sea or Pacific Ocean |chapter=Voyage of Captain William Dampier in the Roebuck to New Holland |volume=4 |publisher=G. & W. Nicol |year=1803 |location=London |page=395}}</ref>
[[File:Schrijver William Dampier in een kleine open prauw op reis naar Aceh (Indonesië), Caspar Luyken, Abraham de Hondt, 1698 - Rijksmuseum.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Men in a small ship in a storm|Engraving of Dampier's encounter with the storm off [[Aceh]], by Caspar Luyken.]] By this time, ''Roebuck'' was in such bad condition that Dampier was forced to abandon his plan to examine the east coast of New Holland while less than a hundred miles from it. In danger of sinking, he attempted to make the return voyage to England, but the ship foundered at [[Ascension Island]] on 21 February 1701.<ref name="nndb"/> While anchored offshore the ship began to take on more water and the carpenter could do nothing with the [[Shipworm|worm]]-eaten planking. As a result, the vessel had to be run aground. Dampier's crew was marooned there for five weeks before being picked up on 3 April by an [[East Indiaman]] and returned home in August 1701.
Although many papers were lost with ''Roebuck'', Dampier was able to save some new charts of coastlines, and his record of [[trade wind]]s and [[Current (ocean)|currents]] in the seas around Australia and New Guinea. He also preserved a few of his specimens. Many plant specimens were donated to the [[Fielding-Druce Herbarium]] (part of the [[University of Oxford]]), and in September 1999, they were then loaned to Western Australia for the 300 year celebration.<ref>Hugh Edwards {{google books|fQiwlGvANE8C|The Buccaneer's Bell|page=86}}</ref> In 2001, the ''Roebuck'' wreck was located in [[Clarence Bay]], Ascension Island, by a team from the [[Western Australian Maritime Museum]].<ref>McCarthy, Michael (2002). [http://www.museum.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/No.%20159%20HMS%20Roebuck.pdf ''Report No. 159: His Majesty’s Ship Roebuck (1690–1701)'']. Fremantle, W.A.: Western Australian Maritime Museum.</ref> Because of his widespread influence, and also because so little exists that can now be linked to him, it has been argued that the remains of his ship and the objects still at the site on Ascension Island – while the property of Britain and subject to the island government's management – are actually the shared maritime heritage of those parts of the world first visited or described by him.<ref>{{cite journal |last=McCarthy |first=Michael |year=2004 |title=HM Ship Roebuck (1690–1701): Global Maritime Heritage? |journal=The International Journal of Nautical Archaeology |volume=33 |issue=2 |pages=330–337 |doi=10.1111/j.1095-9270.2004.00005.x}}</ref> His account of the expedition was published as ''A Voyage to New Holland'' in 1703.
==Court martial== On his return from the ''Roebuck'' expedition, Dampier was [[court-martial]]led for [[cruelty]].<ref name="adob"/> On the outward voyage, Dampier had his [[First lieutenant#Royal Navy|lieutenant]], George Fisher, removed from the ship and jailed in Brazil. Fisher returned to England and complained about his treatment to the Admiralty. Dampier aggressively defended his conduct, but he was found guilty. His pay for the voyage was docked, and he was dismissed from the [[Royal Navy]].
According to records held at the [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|UK's National Archives]],<ref>[http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/ The National Archives]. Records of the Navy Board and the Board of Admiralty. Item reference ADM 1/5262/287.</ref> the Royal Navy court martial held on 8 June 1702 involved the following three charges:
#William Dampier, Captain, HMS ''Roebuck''. #:Crime: Death of John Norwood, boatswain. #:Verdict: Acquitted. #William Dampier, Captain, HMS ''Roebuck''. #:Crime: Hard and cruel usage of the lieutenant. #:Verdict: Guilty. #:Sentence: Forfeit all pay due and deemed unfit to command any of His Majesty's ships. #George Fisher, Lieutenant, HMS ''Roebuck'' #:Crime: Dispute between the captain and the lieutenant. #:Verdict: Acquitted.
==Second circumnavigation== [[File:William Dampier Ecuador2006.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A one-dollar postage stamp portrays Dampier, a Jolly Roger and a sailing ship|An Ecuadorian stamp issued in 2006 commemorates Dampier's piracy in the South Pacific]] The [[War of the Spanish Succession]] had broken out in 1701, and English privateers were being readied to act against French and Spanish interests. Dampier was appointed commander of the 26-gun ship ''St George'', with a crew of 120 men. They were joined by the 16-gun ''[[Cinque Ports (1703 ship)|Cinque Ports]]'' with 63 men, and sailed on 11 September 1703 from [[Kinsale]], Ireland.<ref>{{cite book |title=A Voyage Round the World, Containing an Account of Captain Dampier's Expedition into the South Seas in the Ship St George in the Years 1703 and 1704 |first=William |last=Funnell |year=1707 |publisher=W. Botham |location=London |pages=1–3}}</ref> The two ships made a storm-tossed passage round Cape Horn, arriving at the [[Juan Fernández Islands]] off the coast of Chile in February 1704.<ref>Funnell (1707), pp. 16–17.</ref> While watering and provisioning there, they sighted a heavily armed French merchantman, which they engaged in a seven-hour battle but were driven off.<ref>Funnell (1707), pp. 25–26.</ref>
Dampier succeeded in capturing a number of small Spanish ships along the coast of Peru, but released them after removing only a fraction of their cargoes because he believed they "would be a hindrance to his greater designs."<ref>Funnell (1707), pp. 31–32, 36.</ref> The greater design he had in mind was a raid on Santa María, a town on the [[Gulf of Panama]] rumoured to hold stockpiles of gold from nearby mines. When the force of seamen he led against the town met with unexpectedly strong resistance, however, he withdrew.<ref>Funnell (1707), pp. 39, 45–46.</ref> In May 1704, ''Cinque Ports'' separated from ''St George'' and, after putting [[Alexander Selkirk]] ashore alone on an island for complaining about the vessel's seaworthiness, sank off the coast of what is today Colombia. Some of its crew survived being shipwrecked but were made prisoners of the Spanish.<ref>{{cite book |title=A Cruising Voyage Round the World: First to the South-Sea, Thence to the East-Indies, and Homewards by the Cape of Good Hope |first=Woodes |last=Rogers |year=1712 |publisher=B. Lintot |location=London |pages=145, 333}}</ref>
It was now left to ''St George'' to make an attempt on the [[Manila galleon]], the main object of the expedition. The ship was sighted on 6 December 1704, probably ''Nuestra Señora del Rosario''. It was caught unprepared and had not run out its guns. But while Dampier and his officers argued over the best way to mount an attack, the galleon got its guns loaded and the battle was joined. ''St George'' soon found itself out-sized by the galleon's [[18-pounder long gun|18-]] and [[24-pounder long gun|24-pounders]], and, suffering serious damage, they were forced to break off the attack.<ref>Funnell (1707), pp. 83–84.</ref>
The failure to capture the Spanish galleon completed the break-up of the expedition. Dampier, with about thirty men, stayed in ''St George'', while the rest of the crew took a captured [[barque]] across the Pacific to [[Ambon Island|Amboyna]] in the [[Dutch East Indies|Dutch settlements]]. The undermanned and worm-damaged ''St George'' had to be abandoned on the coast of Peru. He and his remaining men embarked in a Spanish [[Prize ship|prize]] for the East Indies, where they were thrown into prison as pirates by their supposed allies the Dutch but later released.<ref>{{cite book |title=A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels |first=Robert |last=Kerr |publisher=William Blackwood |location=Edinburgh |volume=10 |year=1824 |page=336}}</ref> Now without a ship, Dampier made his way back to England at the end of 1707.
==Third circumnavigation and death== In 1708, Dampier was engaged to serve on the privateer ''Duke'', not as captain but as [[sailing master]].<ref name="adob"/> ''Duke'' beat its way into the South Pacific Ocean round Cape Horn in consort with a second ship, ''Duchess''.<ref>Funnell (1707), pp. 12–13.</ref> Commanded by [[Woodes Rogers]], this voyage was more successful: Selkirk was rescued on 2 February 1709,<ref>Rogers (1712), pp. 124–125.</ref> and the expedition amassed £147,975<ref name="souls">{{cite book |title=Desperate Journeys, Abandoned Souls: True Stories of Castaways and Other Survivors |first=Edward E. |last=Leslie |publisher=Mariner Books |location=New York |year=1988 |page=83 |isbn=978-039-54-7864-6}}</ref> (equivalent to £{{Formatprice|{{Inflation|UK|147975|1713|r=-5}}}} today){{Inflation-fn|UK|df=y}} worth of plundered goods. Most of that came from the capture of a Spanish galleon, ''[[Spanish ship Nuestra Señora de la Encarnación y Desengaño|Nuestra Señora de la Encarnación y Desengaño]]'', along the coast of Mexico in December 1709.<ref>Rogers (1712), pp. 293–294.</ref>
In January 1710, Dampier crossed the Pacific in ''Duke'', accompanied by ''Duchess'' and two prizes. They stopped at Guam before arriving in [[Jakarta|Batavia]]. Following a refit at Horn Island (near Batavia) and the sale of one of their prize ships, they sailed for the Cape of Good Hope where they remained for more than three months awaiting a [[convoy]]. They left the Cape in company with 25 Dutch and English ships, with Dampier now serving as sailing master of ''Encarnación''.<ref>{{cite book |first=Edward |last=Cooke |year=1712 |title=A Voyage to the South Sea and Round the World, Performed in the Years 1708, 1709, 1710 and 1711 |volume=2 |publisher=B. Lintot |location=London |page=61}}</ref> After a further delay at the [[Texel]], they dropped anchor at the [[Thames]] in London on 14 October 1711.<ref>Rogers (1712), p. 428.</ref>
Dampier may not have lived to receive all of his share of the expedition's gains.<ref name="souls"/> He died in the [[St Stephen Coleman Street|Parish of St Stephen Coleman Street]], London.<ref>{{cite journal |title=A Biographical Sketch of Captain Dampier |journal=United Service Journal |date=July 1837 |first=William Henry |last=Smyth |page=70}}</ref> The exact date and circumstances of his death, and his final resting place, are all unknown. His will was proven on 23 March 1715, and it is generally assumed he died earlier that month, but this is not known with any certainty.<ref>Preston & Preston (2005), p. 447.</ref> His estate was almost £2,000 in debt.<ref>{{cite book |last=Souhami |first=Diana |year=2001 |title=Selkirk's Island: The True and Strange Adventures of the Real Robinson Crusoe |location=New York |publisher=Harcourt Books |isbn=978-015-60-2717-5 |page=184}}</ref>
==Legacy== [[File:Rime of the Ancient Mariner-Albatross-Dore.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Engraving of seventeen sailors and an albatross on a sailing ship's ice-covered deck|Sailors in the [[South Pacific Ocean|South Sea]] gape at an albatross perched on the icy deck, in ''The Rime of the Ancient Mariner''. Engraving by [[Gustave Doré]].]] Dampier influenced several figures better known than he: * He made important contributions to [[navigation]], collecting for the first time data on currents, winds and tides across all the world’s oceans that was used by [[James Cook]] and [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Horatio Nelson]].<ref name="wam">[http://museum.wa.gov.au/about/latest-news/william-dampier-pirate-and-travel-writer "William Dampier, Pirate and Travel Writer"]. Western Australian Museum. Retrieved 29 September 2013</ref> * His travel journals depicting Panama may have influenced the undertaking of the ill-fated [[Darien Scheme]], leading to the [[Act of Union of 1707]].<ref>[http://www.futuremuseum.co.uk/collections/people/key-people/trade,-commerce-industry/william-paterson-the-darien-scheme.aspx "William Patterson and the Darien Scheme"]. Future Museum of Southwest Scotland. Retrieved 29 September 2013.</ref> * [[Daniel Defoe]], author of ''[[Robinson Crusoe]]'', was likely inspired by accounts of real-life [[castaway]] [[Alexander Selkirk]], a crew member on Dampier's voyages.<ref>{{cite book |first=Tim |last=Severin |year=2002 |title=In Search of Robinson Crusoe |publisher=Basic Books |location=New York |pages=17–19 |isbn=978-046-50-7698-7}}</ref> * [[Jonathan Swift]] explicitly mentions Dampier in his ''[[Gulliver's Travels]]'' as a mariner comparable to [[Lemuel Gulliver]].<ref name="ocean">[http://ocean.si.edu/ocean-news/pirate-who-collected-plants/famous-people-dampier-influenced "The Pirate Who Collected Plants: Famous People Dampier Influenced"]. Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History. Retrieved 29 September 2013.</ref> * His notes on the fauna and flora of north-western Australia were studied by naturalist and scientist [[Joseph Banks]],<ref name="wam" /> who made further studies during the first voyage with James Cook. This helped lead to the naming of and colonisation of [[Botany Bay]] and the founding of modern Australia. * His reports on [[breadfruit]] led to [[William Bligh]]'s ill-fated voyage in [[HMS Bounty|HMS ''Bounty'']].<ref>[http://www.lookandlearn.com/blog/21798/captain-bligh-introduced-breadfruit-to-the-west-indies/ "Captain Bligh Introduced Breadfruit to the West Indies"]. ''Look and Learn''. Retrieved 29 September 2013.</ref> * Another storied crew mate of Dampier, [[Simon Hatley]], who is best remembered for shooting an albatross while his ship battled storms off Cape Horn, influenced the writing of [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]]'s poem ''[[The Rime of the Ancient Mariner]]''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Holmes |first=Richard |year=1989 |title=Coleridge: Early Visions, 1772–1804 |location=New York |publisher=Pantheon Books |isbn=978-067-08-0444-3 |pages=171–172}}</ref> * His observations and analysis of [[natural history]] helped [[Alexander von Humboldt]] and [[Charles Darwin]] develop their scientific theories.<ref name="ocean"/> * His observations (and those of Mr William Funnell) during his expeditions are mentioned several times by [[Alfred Russel Wallace]] in his book ''[[The Malay Archipelago]]'', and compared to his own observations made on his 19th-century voyages.<ref>{{cite book |last=Wallace |first=Alfred R. |year=1869 |title=The Malay Archipelago: The Land of the Orangutan, and the Bird of Paradise—A Narrative of Travel, with Sketches of Man and Nature |location=London |publisher=Macmillan |pages=196, 205, 300}}</ref> * He is cited over 80 times in the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'', notably on words such as "[[barbecue]]", "[[avocado]]", "[[chopsticks]]" and "[[sub-species]]".<ref>{{cite book |last=Mitchell |first=Adrian |title=Dampier's Monkey: the South Seas Voyages of William Dampier |year=2010 |publisher=Wakefield Press |location=Kent Town, S.A. |isbn=978-186-25-4759-9 |pages=173}}</ref> That is not to say he coined the words, but his use of them in his writings is the first known example in English.
==Negative depiction of Aborigines== In his journal, 'A New Voyage Around The World', Dampier depicted the first inhabitants of Australia as virtually subhuman, likening them to monkeys and calling them the "miserabilist" people he had ever seen.<ref>{{cite web |title=How explorer and pirate William Dampier's comments on Aboriginal people in 1697 set the tone for future sentiment |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-11-04/william-dampiers-terra-nullius-set-the-tone-for-australia/10420338 |website=ABC news |accessdate=3 November 2018}}</ref> This may have been at the behest of the publisher who wanted to cater to public prejudice and increase sales. Dampier spent two months in the peninsular, now named after him, observing the people of that area, the Bardi people. They had been there for thousands of years and were actually a well organised society. In his private journals Dampier did seem to have more respect. Nevertheless, it has been claimed that Dampier set the tone for future explorers and colonisers of Australia, which led to the law of [[terra nullius]], the view that the land was unoccupied and there for the taking.
==Honours== The following geographical places/features are named after William Dampier: * [[Dampier, Western Australia|Dampier]], a town and major port of [[Western Australia]]; * [[Dampier Archipelago]], Western Australia; * [[Dampier County]], a [[Cadastre|cadastral division]] of New South Wales; * Dampier Island, an island of the Dampier Archipelago, Western Australia, renamed [[Burrup Peninsula]] in the 1960s when it was connected to the mainland by a causeway; * [[Dampier Land District]], a cadastral division of Western Australia; * [[Dampier Peninsula]], Western Australia; * Dampier Ridge, part of the submerged continent of [[Zealandia (continent)|Zealandia]]; * [[Mount Dampier]], the third highest peak in [[New Zealand]];<ref>http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/european-discovery-of-new-zealand/page-9</ref> * Dampier Seamount, off the island of [[Saint Helena]]; * [[Dampier Strait (Indonesia)]]; * [[Dampier Strait (Papua New Guinea)]]; * the [[Division of Dampier]], an electorate of the [[Australian House of Representatives]] from 1913 to 1922; * Dampier Road, Bristol, England; * the [[minor planet]] [[14876 Dampier]];<ref>MPC [http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/ECS/MPCArchive/2015/MPC_20150602.pdf 94384]</ref> * a British frigate/survey ship, {{HMS|Dampier|K611|6}}, in service with the Royal Navy between 1948 and 1968; and * postage stamps bearing his portrait issued by [[Australia Post]] in 1966 and 1985.<ref>[http://www.australianstamp.com/images/large/0015390.jpg Australia SG 974 33 cent, Bicentenary of Australian Settlement, Navigators, "William Dampier" (1988)]. Australian Stamp and Coin. Retrieved 13 September 2011.</ref>
